deliberation: Checked for imagery beyond the standard prophetic formula. The only potentially figurative element is 'the word of YHWH came to me', which personifies 'word' as if it travels. This is a conventional prophetic personification/metaphor for receiving revelation.

instances.english_text: The word of GOD came to me
ground: Initiative and directed movement from sender to recipient
Active arrival and encounter
Communication dynamics
posture: Stresses the divine initiative and authority of the message
instances.explanation: The 'word' of YHWH is personified and metaphorically portrayed as something that comes to Ezekiel like a visiting entity, expressing the experiential reality of receiving revelation.

deliberation: Looked for metaphors or personifications in the command to prophesy and to wail. The only figurative nuance is in 'for the day', where 'day' stands for the coming event/judgment, a standard prophetic metonymy.

instances.english_text: Wail, alas for the day!
target: Impending judgment on Egypt (and related nations)
ground: Association of a time-point with a defining event
Focusing the entire complex of disaster into a single imminent occasion
Event-time linkage
posture: Urgent lament over the coming disaster
instances.explanation: The 'day' is not just a literal calendar day but stands metonymically for the full complex of coming calamities; the audience is told to lament that event by referring to it as 'the day'.

deliberation: Multiple 'day' expressions appear. I distinguished the technical 'day of YHWH' (time for divine judgment) as metonymy, and 'day of cloud' as a metaphor that likens the judgment day to a dark, stormy day.

instances.english_text: A day of GOD is near
ground: A specific time that is characterized by decisive action of its owner
Concentration of complex events into one appointed occasion
Ownership and determination of time
posture: Announces the imminence and certainty of YHWH’s intervention
instances.explanation: The 'day of YHWH' is a standard prophetic metonymy, where 'day' stands for the extended event of divine judgment rather than a mere 24-hour period.

instances.english_text: a day of cloud
target: The nature of the coming judgment-day
Emotional and experiential quality of the event
ground: Darkness, obscurity, foreboding, and fear
Lack of clarity and joy
Negative experiential qualities
posture: Presents the judgment as ominous and oppressive
instances.explanation: Calling it 'a day of cloud' metaphorically depicts the judgment as dark and threatening, evoking imagery of storm and gloom rather than literal weather forecast.

deliberation: Considered whether 'sword' and 'foundations' are literal. 'Sword' is standard metonymy for warfare/military attack. 'Her foundations are overthrown' treats Egypt as a building whose foundations are destroyed, a structural metaphor for the collapse of basic institutions.

instances.english_text: A sword shall [come] into Egypt
target: Military invasion and warfare against Egypt
ground: Instrument of lethal force and warfare
Association of sword with battle and death
Instrument-action linkage
posture: Announces divinely ordained warfare against Egypt
instances.explanation: The 'sword' is a metonymy for warfare and invading armies, not a single physical blade entering the land.

instances.english_text: and her foundations are overthrown
target: Egypt’s basic social, political, and economic structures
vehicle: The foundations of a building being demolished
ground: What supports and holds up the whole entity is destroyed, leading to collapse
Radical destabilization
Loss of support and security
posture: Portrays Egypt’s collapse as total and structural, not superficial
instances.explanation: Egypt is metaphorically portrayed as a building whose very foundations are demolished, signaling the destruction of its underlying systems.

deliberation: Names of nations are literal. The phrase 'fall by the sword' is a conventional idiom where 'sword' stands metonymically for death in battle.

instances.english_text: shall fall by the sword with them
target: The deaths of these allied peoples in war
vehicle: The sword as a killing weapon
ground: Swords are primary tools of killing in battle
Association of 'sword' with violent death
Instrument-result linkage
posture: Depicts their fate as violent and ignominious
instances.explanation: To 'fall by the sword' uses 'sword' metonymically for violent death in warfare; it is not about literal tripping over a weapon.

deliberation: I considered 'supporters of Egypt' and 'her proud strength shall come down'. The former can be literal allies. 'Proud strength shall sink/go down' is metaphorical, using vertical movement to depict humiliation. 'From Migdol to Syene' is a spatial merism for all Egypt.

instances.english_text: And her proud strength shall sink
vehicle: Something high that descends or collapses downward
Vertical movement from height to low place
ground: Loss of exalted status; humiliation and weakening
From high and secure to low and vulnerable
Status-loss correspondence
posture: Depicts Egypt’s pride as being humbled by divine judgment
Negative evaluative stance toward that pride
instances.explanation: Egypt’s arrogant power is portrayed as something elevated that is forced to go down, a spatial metaphor for humiliation.

instances.english_text: From Migdol to Syene
target: The entire geographic span of Egypt
vehicle: Two extreme boundary towns (north and south)
ground: Naming extremities to imply inclusion of everything between
Boundary-as-totality expression
Range-covering logic
posture: Stresses totality of the judgment across all Egypt
instances.explanation: The pairing of the northern and southern extremities functions as a merism, expressing that the whole land in between is included in the judgment.

deliberation: The verse uses superlative language: 'most desolate of desolate lands' and 'most ruined of cities'. That is an intensifying hyperbole rather than a precise, literal measure of desolation.

instances.hebrew_text: וְנָשַׁמּוּ בְּתוֹךְ אֲרָצוֹת נְשַׁמּוֹת וְעָרָיו בְּתוֹךְ־עָרִים נַחֲרָבוֹת תִּהְיֶינָה
instances.english_text: They shall be the most desolate of desolate lands, and her cities shall be the most ruined of cities
target: The degree of devastation that will befall Egypt and its cities
vehicle: Superlative comparison among all desolate lands and ruined cities
ground: Use of extreme language to emphasize extraordinary desolation
Not literal statistics but emphatic intensity
Rhetorical overstatement
posture: Highlights the severity of judgment by overstating desolation
instances.explanation: By calling Egypt the most desolate among desolate lands and its cities the most ruined among ruined cities, the text uses hyperbolic superlatives to underscore the extremity of devastation.

deliberation: Examined whether 'fire' is literal. The phrase 'I set fire to Egypt' in this broader oracle functions as a stock metaphor for devastating judgment (war, destruction), not merely literal burning.

instances.english_text: when I set fire to Egypt
target: Divine judgment and large-scale destruction in Egypt
vehicle: A consuming fire burning through Egypt
ground: Fire consumes, destroys, and leaves desolation
Associates judgment with rapid, unstoppable devastation
Destructive power parallel
posture: Presents the judgment as fierce and consuming
instances.explanation: Fire is used metaphorically for the destructive force of divine judgment (likely via invading armies), not for a single literal blaze covering all Egypt.

deliberation: Messengers in ships can be literal. 'Egypt’s day' is shorthand for its day of doom, a time-for-event metonymy similar to 'day of YHWH'.

instances.english_text: on Egypt’s day
ground: Using a day to encapsulate the defining event that characterizes it
Time-standing-for-event
Event-temporal association
posture: Frames Egypt’s downfall as an appointed, inevitable moment
instances.explanation: ‘Egypt’s day’ is a metonymy in which a temporal point stands for the catastrophic event that defines it—Egypt’s day of doom.

deliberation: Considered 'I will cause the hāmōn of Egypt to cease'. Though 'hāmōn' can be pomp/multitude/wealth, the verse can straightforwardly refer to ending Egypt’s population/pomp through Nebuchadnezzar. The language can be read literally without clear figurative mechanism, so I treat it as non-figurative here.
Looked at 'unsheathe the sword' and 'fill the land with the slain'. The latter is clearly hyperbolic; the land cannot literally be filled, but this exaggerates the number of corpses.

instances.english_text: and they shall fill the land with the slain
target: The extent of deaths caused by the invasion
vehicle: A land being filled up with corpses as with objects or material
ground: Overwhelming number and omnipresence of the dead
Exaggeration to convey vast scale
Quantity-intensity link
posture: Drives home the horror and scale of the bloodshed
instances.explanation: The statement that the land will be ‘filled’ with the slain is hyperbolic imagery, overstating to stress the enormity of the slaughter.

deliberation: Distinguished literal from figurative. Drying up the channels could be literal or symbolic. 'I will sell the land into the hand of evildoers' uses commercial language for political transfer of control, a metaphorical idiom.

instances.english_text: and I will sell the land into the hands of evildoers
target: Transfer of Egypt’s control to wicked foreign rulers
vehicle: A commercial sale of land to buyers
ground: Deliberate transfer of ownership/rights from one party to another
Loss of former owner’s control and benefit
Ownership/control parallel
posture: Portrays Egypt’s loss of sovereignty as YHWH’s deliberate disposal of it
instances.explanation: Using sale language metaphorically, God depicts handing Egypt over to wicked rulers as if the land were a commodity sold into their hands.

deliberation: Idol destruction and absence of a prince are literal. 'I will put fear in the land of Egypt' uses 'land' for its inhabitants (metonymy) and treats the land as the seat of fear, a mild personification.

instances.english_text: and I will strike the land of Egypt with fear / I will put fear in the land of Egypt
target: The people of Egypt experiencing pervasive terror
vehicle: The land of Egypt as a container into which fear is placed
ground: The inhabitants are so identified with the land that the land can stand for them and be described as filled with fear
Fear being pervasive throughout the territory
Container-content association
posture: Depicts fear as God’s imposed judgment on Egypt
instances.explanation: The ‘land’ stands metonymically for its inhabitants, and it is personified as a realm into which God places fear, conveying an all-pervasive terror among the people.

deliberation: Laying Pathros waste, setting fire to Zoan, and executing judgments in No can all be read in straightforward military-conquest terms; no necessary figurative device beyond ordinary description. I treat them as literal.
The key figurative expression is 'I will pour out my wrath', a common biblical metaphor conceptualizing anger as a liquid that can be poured upon someone.

instances.english_text: I will pour out my anger upon Sin, the stronghold of Egypt
target: God’s enactment of punitive judgment on the city of Sin
vehicle: Liquid being poured out from a container
ground: Abundant, directed release that covers the object
Unrestrained outflow that affects the recipient completely
Quantity-direction parallel
posture: Stresses the intensity and intentionality of God’s punitive action
instances.explanation: Wrath is metaphorically treated as a liquid that God pours out on Sin, portraying the judgment as abundant, directed, and overwhelming.

deliberation: Two distinct figures: (1) 'I will set fire to Egypt' again uses fire metaphorically for judgment. (2) 'Sin shall writhe in anguish' personifies the city as a suffering human, using a verb often used for labor pains or severe distress.

instances.english_text: I will set fire to Egypt
target: The comprehensive devastation that will come upon Egypt
ground: Fire’s ability to consume and devastate extensively
Sudden, destructive judgment leaving ruin
Destruction-intensity parallel
posture: Depicts judgment as fierce and all-consuming
instances.explanation: As in v. 8, fire symbolizes the destructive power of divine judgment, likely mediated through war and invasion.

instances.english_text: Sin shall writhe in anguish
target: The city of Sin and its experience under judgment
vehicle: A person writhing in pain (often childbirth or mortal anguish)
ground: Intense, uncontrollable suffering and fear
Convulsive reaction to severe pain or terror
Distress parallel
posture: Presents the city’s fate as deeply agonizing
instances.explanation: The city of Sin is personified as a human writhing in severe pain, conveying the extremity of its distress under divine judgment.

deliberation: The towns and young men are literal. The phrase 'fall by the sword' again uses 'sword' metonymically for death in battle.

instances.english_text: shall fall by the sword
target: The killing of the young men of Aven and Pi-beseth
vehicle: The sword as implement of killing
ground: Swords as standard tools of warfare and killing
Short-hand for violent death in combat
Instrument-result association
posture: Depicts their fate as violent and military in nature
instances.explanation: As elsewhere, 'fall by the sword' uses 'sword' as a metonymy for violent death in battle.

deliberation: This verse is rich in imagery: (1) 'The day shall be dark' uses darkness for calamity. (2) 'I break the bars/staves of Egypt' is a power-as-support metaphor. (3) '[The city] itself shall be covered with cloud' uses cloud as gloom/judgment image. (4) 'Her daughter towns' treats dependent towns as daughters, a kinship metaphor.

instances.english_text: In Tehaphnehes daylight shall be withheld / the day shall grow dark
target: The overall condition of calamity and loss in Tehaphnehes
vehicle: A day becoming dark, loss of light
ground: Darkness connotes misfortune, fear, and the end of joy
Loss of clarity, hope, and normalcy
Light–prosperity vs. dark–calamity
posture: Frames the judgment as turning a bright day into gloom
instances.explanation: The darkened day is metaphorical for the city’s transition from normal life to disaster and anguish, using darkness as a symbol of calamity.

instances.english_text: when I break there the bars/staffs of Egypt
target: Egypt’s supporting power structures (military, political strength)
vehicle: Bars or staffs that support and uphold something
ground: Breaking supporting bars causes collapse or inability to bear weight
Loss of structural support parallels loss of power
Support–power correspondence
posture: Depicts God as shattering Egypt’s ability to sustain itself
instances.explanation: Egypt’s power is metaphorically represented as ‘bars’ or ‘staffs’ that support it; breaking them describes the dismantling of its strength.

instances.english_text: [The city] itself shall be covered with cloud
target: The state of Tehaphnehes under judgment
City’s condition of gloom and confusion
vehicle: A cloud covering a person or place
ground: Cloud-cover implies gloom, obscurity, and overshadowing trouble
Loss of brightness and visibility corresponds to distress and uncertainty
Gloom–trouble parallel
posture: Portrays the city as under a pall of divine judgment
instances.explanation: The city is personified as being covered by a cloud, using the image of cloud-cover to depict pervasive gloom and judgment.

instances.english_text: and its daughter towns shall go into captivity
vehicle: Daughters in relation to a mother city
ground: Close, dependent relationship of smaller towns to a primary city parallels daughters to a mother
Shared fate with subordinate status
Dependency analogy
posture: Shows the spread of judgment from the main city to its dependents
instances.explanation: The smaller towns are metaphorically called the city’s ‘daughters’, personifying the urban network as a family, to show that the whole ‘family’ goes into captivity.

deliberation: The verse summarizes: 'I will execute judgments on Egypt; and they shall know that I am YHWH.' This is theological but not figurative; no metaphors, similes, or personifications are required to understand it.
Same prophetic formula as v. 1: 'the word of YHWH came to me'. Again this personifies the 'word' and metaphorically depicts revelation as something that comes to the prophet.

instances.english_text: the word of GOD came to me
vehicle: A word that travels and arrives at a person
ground: Active movement from sender to receiver expresses initiative and encounter
Revelation as an event of coming
Communication dynamics
posture: Stresses the authoritative, God-initiated character of the message
instances.explanation: As in v. 1, the phrase personifies and metaphorically animates the divine word as coming to Ezekiel, expressing the experience of receiving revelation.

deliberation: The entire verse develops an extended metaphor: Pharaoh’s 'arm' broken, unbandaged, unable to grasp the sword. 'Arm' stands for military/political strength, and its breaking for crippling that power.

instances.hebrew_text: אֶת־זְרוֹעַ פַּרְעֹה מֶלֶךְ־מִצְרַיִם שָׁבַרְתִּי ... לְחַזְקָהּ לִתְפֹּשׂ בֶּחָרֶב
instances.english_text: I have broken the arm of Pharaoh king of Egypt; it has not been bound up ... to make it strong enough to grasp the sword
vehicle: A human arm that is broken, unhealed, and unable to hold a weapon
ground: A broken arm removes the ability to fight effectively
Incapacity, weakness, vulnerability
Function-loss parallel
posture: Highlights Pharaoh’s irreversible loss of effective power as God’s judgment
instances.explanation: Pharaoh’s 'arm' is a metonymy for his power and is metaphorically described as broken and unhealed, portraying his military impotence.

deliberation: Continues the arm imagery: God will break both of Pharaoh’s arms and cause the sword to fall from his hand. This extends the same metaphor of military power as arms that wield a sword.

instances.english_text: I will break his arms, both the sound one and the injured, and make the sword drop from his hand
target: Pharaoh’s remaining capacity for resistance and warfare
vehicle: Both arms of a warrior being broken so he drops his sword
ground: Without functioning arms one cannot hold or wield a weapon, implying total incapacity
Complete removal of combat ability
Strength–weapon linkage
posture: Depicts God as decisively and completely disabling Pharaoh’s power
instances.explanation: Both 'arms' are Pharaoh’s powers, and the image of breaking them so that he drops the sword powerfully depicts his total military collapse.

deliberation: The verbs 'scatter' and 'disperse' present exile as scattering objects (like seed) across lands. This is a conventional metaphor for forced diaspora.

instances.english_text: I will scatter the Egyptians among the nations and disperse them throughout the countries
target: The forced exile and diaspora of Egyptians
vehicle: Scattering and winnowing objects like seed or chaff by hand or wind
ground: Loss of cohesion and concentration; being spread out and separated
From unity in one place to scattered many places
Spatial-distribution parallel
posture: Presents the exile as a divinely driven dispersal, not random
instances.explanation: The exiles are metaphorically portrayed as objects scattered and winnowed among nations, depicting the loss of national cohesion.

deliberation: Two figures: (1) 'Strengthen the arms of the king of Babylon' is the positive counterpart to the Pharaoh-arm metaphor—arms for power. (2) 'He shall groan with the groans of one struck down' compares Pharaoh’s lament to that of a mortally wounded man, an implicit simile/metaphor of extreme distress.

instances.hebrew_text: וְחִזַּקְתִּי אֶת־זְרֹעוֹת מֶלֶךְ בָּבֶל וְנָתַתִּי אֶת־חַרְבִּי בְּיָדוֹ
instances.english_text: I will strengthen the arms of the king of Babylon and put My sword in his hand
target: The empowerment of the Babylonian king as agent of God’s judgment
ground: Strong arms wielding a weapon signify effective fighting power
Equipping with a sword implies authorization and capacity
Strength–weapon–agency linkage
posture: Portrays Babylon’s might as divinely granted for purposes of judgment
Affirmative toward Babylon as instrument, judicial toward Egypt
instances.explanation: The Babylonian king’s political-military power is depicted as strong arms holding God’s own sword, a metaphor for God empowering him as His instrument.

instances.english_text: and he shall groan before him with the groans of one struck down
target: Pharaoh’s anguish and humiliation before the Babylonian king
vehicle: The groaning of a mortally wounded man
ground: Deep, involuntary cries of pain and defeat
Ultimate vulnerability and powerlessness
Suffering-intensity parallel
posture: Depicts Pharaoh’s fall as utterly devastating
instances.explanation: Pharaoh’s lament is likened to the groans of a slain man, an implicit simile/metaphor for his extreme agony and absolute defeat.

deliberation: Reiterates the arm-and-sword imagery: Babylon’s arms made firm, Pharaoh’s arms falling, God’s sword in Babylon’s hand stretched out against Egypt. This is one coherent martial metaphor for divinely empowered vs. disabled power.

instances.hebrew_text: וְהַחֲזַקְתִּי אֶת־זְרֹעוֹת מֶלֶךְ בָּבֶל וּזְרֹעוֹת פַּרְעֹה תִּפֹּלְנָה ... בְּתִתִּי חַרְבִּי בְּיַד מֶלֶךְ־בָּבֶל וְנָטָה אוֹתָהּ אֶל־אֶרֶץ מִצְרָיִם
instances.english_text: I will make firm the arms of the king of Babylon, but the arms of Pharaoh shall fail ... when I put My sword into the hand of the king of Babylon, and he lifts it against the land of Egypt
target: Relative empowerment of Babylon and disempowerment of Egypt
vehicle: Strong vs. failing arms and a sword stretched out against a foe
Contrasting warriors, one armed with God’s sword
ground: Strong arms with a sword imply effective, victorious power; failing arms without a sword imply incapacity and defeat
Directing a sword against someone signifies attack and judgment
Strength–weapon–victory correspondence
posture: Affirms Babylon as God’s instrument while depicting Egypt as judged and helpless
instances.explanation: Arms symbolize political-military strength, and God’s sword in Babylon’s hand portrays Babylon as the empowered executor of God’s judgment over a powerless Pharaoh.

deliberation: Repeats v. 23’s exile language. Again, 'scatter' and 'disperse' are metaphors presenting the forced dispersion of Egypt’s population as scattering objects across countries.

instances.hebrew_text: וַהֲפִצוֹתִי אֶת־מִצְרַיִם בַּגּוֹיִם וְזֵרִיתִי אוֹתָם בָּאֲרָצוֹת
instances.english_text: I will scatter the Egyptians among the nations and disperse them throughout the countries
target: The exile and diaspora of Egyptians
vehicle: Scattering objects (like seed or chaff) widely
ground: From a compact group to widely separated individuals in different places
Loss of unity and coherence
Distribution/disintegration parallel
posture: Presents exile as a deliberate act of divine judgment causing national disintegration
instances.explanation: Egypt’s people are portrayed metaphorically as items scattered abroad, vividly depicting the breaking up of the nation through exile.
